reviewText:
I was all but ready to give Ducktales: Remastered a positive review, despite what had been the occasional shonky control error, the obsolete inclusion of a lives system, and the cutscenes beginning to wear thin, because... Well, it's Ducktales, isn't it, in every way that matters. The spirit is there, and it evokes it brilliantly, taking what the NES game had presented to us before and updating it visually into something incredibly pleasing on a key aesthetic level.

And then the final level happened. The occasional control issue only gets worse when the game demands more from you, and so what should have been a triumphant finale to a decent enough game became frustratingly hard, through no fault of my own (not that I'd say I'm great at games, it's just that the issues were definitely on the game's part in this instance. That, followed by an awkward final boss and an extra platforming section where that lack of responsiveness stops you getting through a fiddly, precision-demanding bit of timed jumping.

Theres ways it could have been better, something like removing the lives system, or even just having a checkpointed continue option upon game over, but to demand that a player go through every problematic moment over and over just to get to whatever stumbling block they last came to. There's an argument to be made that changes such as these weren't made to preserve the original game's intent, but when you call your game a remastering you may as well go all out, yeah?

reviewText:
Ducktales remastered is a remake of the classic NES game. I’ve never played the original NES game, so even without the nostalgia glasses, I still think Ducktales remastered is a wonderful game with some minor flaws.

The game features a 2.5d look with hand drawn sprites and backgrounds and they look amazing. The redone themes are catchy, memorable, and kickass. They also brought back the original actors to voice the characters. The controls are tight and responsive. There is plenty to unlock with the gems you collect from character art, music, and even sketches from the show.

Some of my minor gripes with the game are the cut scenes are fairly frequent and take you out of the experience. Every time you find an item there’s a cut scene. While you can skip them you have to do so manually, there is no option to skip all cut scenes.

Ducktales also isn’t for everyone. It features the classic NES difficulty if you lose all your lives you have to replay the level from the start. I found the game to be challenging but fair. The game only became frustrating at the very end where you have race to the top.

Overall Ducktales is a great and challenging platforming game that still holds up well after two decades.

reviewText:
If you liked the original NES game you will get some nice nostalgia out of this one. It stays true to the original while hotting up the graphics and adds a few extra levels. Only bad thing is the way you cancel cinematics. The cinematics are ok the first time you play through the game, but this is a game that you most likely will play again and again, doing the different difficulty levels, the achievements, farming gold to buy all the items in the gallery and so on. And when running through a level the fifth time you probably will want to skip them.

Instead of beaning able to instant cancel them with a single button click or even have the possibility with an option to skip all cinematics you manually have to bring up the menu and choose to the “cancel cinematic” alternative every time a cinematic pops up.

reviewText:
I was all but ready to give Ducktales: Remastered a positive review, despite what had been the occasional shonky control error, the obsolete inclusion of a lives system, and the cutscenes beginning to wear thin, because... Well, it's Ducktales, isn't it, in every way that matters. The spirit is there, and it evokes it brilliantly, taking what the NES game had presented to us before and updating it visually into something incredibly pleasing on a key aesthetic level.

And then the final level happened. The occasional control issue only gets worse when the game demands more from you, and so what should have been a triumphant finale to a decent enough game became frustratingly hard, through no fault of my own (not that I'd say I'm great at games, it's just that the issues were definitely on the game's part in this instance. That, followed by an awkward final boss and an extra platforming section where that lack of responsiveness stops you getting through a fiddly, precision-demanding bit of timed jumping.

Theres ways it could have been better, something like removing the lives system, or even just having a checkpointed continue option upon game over, but to demand that a player go through every problematic moment over and over just to get to whatever stumbling block they last came to. There's an argument to be made that changes such as these weren't made to preserve the original game's intent, but when you call your game a remastering you may as well go all out, yeah?

reviewText:
A loving homage to the series, complete with all the original voice actors.  The game is pretty similar to the original NES version, with slightly expanded levels and a couple new ones.  There's updated versions of the music tracks, with the option to use the original NES BGMs if you prefer, and a number of gallery unlocks with lots of concept art and such.

I have only two major complaints:
-It's quite short and pretty pricey for the hours you'll get out of it (at full price); buying it on deep discount is strongly recommended
-There's actually too much inter-level dialogue, and it really breaks up the pacing of the game.  I get they wanted to put the voice actors to work, but this is a simple action platformer and we don't need several minutes of dialogue every time you find a plot coupon.

If you were a fan as a kid and you're looking to be nostalga bombed, this is highly recommended.  The gameplay is still solid as well.

reviewText: The sort of game Wayforward excels at, a true throwback to NES platformers. reviewText:
An amazing remake of a great NES game.

I loved Duck Tales for the NES. Its actually the first NES game i ever beat as a kid.  So i was really excited when i heard about this remake. and it did not dissapoint.

This is how a remake should be done.  They didn't just go back and redo the sprites and remaster the music.  They added all new levels, and revamped the original levels and bosses.  And they fleshed out the story with lines voiced by the original cast of the show!

The game is classic NES challenge but now has difficulty settings which effect lives and starting health so even if your not up old school challenge you'll likely be able to get through this game with a little pratice.  There are tons of extra unlockables like concept art and music from both the remake and the classic game.

My only minor complaint is since you can unlock art and music of the original NES game, i think it would have been an especially nice touch to be able unlock the original game itself but alas no such luck.  Still can't hold that against them when what we've been given is so great.   If you loved the show or enjoy oldschool platformers then this is well worth $15

reviewText:
Overall, the game is an awesome remake of the NES original. At full price, I think the $15.00 is a little much, but sale price around $7.00 is fine for about a 5 hour game, which you can spend more time on if you want to 100%.

I'm still going to go with others and give this a thumbs down. There is a game breaking bug at the end for many users. You will make it all the way to the final boss and have the game freeze and need to restart. I did this twice before I went to the forums to find others with the same issue. The fact that the developer has not addressed this is pretty ridiculous.

I was able to work around the bug using suggestions from users on the forums, but I shouldn't have to download a third party program to get a game to run correctly. Good game, but can't recommend a purchase at full price, or with the game breaking bug that so many users have.

reviewText: As a staple of my own childhood, DuckTales Remastered is a dream come true. The levels stay incredibly faithful to the original game's design, the graphics are crisp and colorful and the soundtrack is incredible. I would have said that WayForward did an amazing job, had it not been for one major flaw; the hit detection. This has been something that has plagued any retro" style game
date: whether it be remakes of old games or brand new ones. The hit detection in DuckTales is not only poorly presented but also incredibly frustrating. For example
recommended: pogo-ing onto enemies with just outside of their hitbox results in you taking damage
hoursPlayed: even though graphically it shows itself as landing the hit. Another example is during the Amazon boss battle

reviewText:
While the game retains the same gameplay and enjoyment of the original, it has some very giant flaws that I cannot believe or understand how the developers allowed to exist.

The first major flaw is the hit boxes. Either the enemy or Scrooge's hitboxes are way too liberal. Now, I'm not saying it needs to be pixel perfect, but it needs to be within reason of the pixels which, in many places, it is not even remotely close. So the hitboxes are really bad and loose in a lot of places.

The second major flaw is, for enemies that take multiple hits (See bosses), they get an invincibility to them after each damaging hit, which is completely reasonable, however they then become like ghosts and you can move through them. This is bad because often by the time you are getting away or through them, they come back into being solid and then hurt you, all because they don't retain their physical parameters during invicibility. This could have easily been resolved by either giving a shorter invicibility length or by simply making them not become ghost-like on hit.

Other than those two flaws, the game is very fun and quite enjoyable.

reviewText:
As a fan of both the original DuckTales NES game and DuckTales media in general, I seem to be this game's target audience.

The gameplay is solid, unquestionably built off of the original.

The graphics are beautiful.  The 2D, hand drawn art is excellent, matching the character design faithfully, and it meshes well with the 3D backgrounds.  The voices are just as excellent as they always were thanks to the talent of the actors fans have long known and loved, although lines may feel stilted as the timing of each line's seems to have been set by the engine without much regard for the performance.

The music is good.  It doesn't quite seem to know if it wants to be an epic, synth-orchestra take on the original or if it wants to be chiptune homage, and so it doesn't seem to hit the heights of either style.  It also loses some impact when voice samples are played over it before it has had a chance to make its full impression.

The control is very fluid, much more so than the original game.  This feels good at times, but it does not always work well with the gameplay.  In the NES game, the necessity to commit to certain motions (like a jump arc) was not a problem thanks to the fact that the environments were well aligned to your control capabilities.  Here, the extra fluidity means that I cannot have as much confidence of my choices in movement.  And as such I cannot feel as though I know for sure where I should be aiming in tricky jumps, etc.  It is something I will get over with time, but that solid"
date: "sure" control from the original game is not quite replicated here
recommended: and it caused a great deal of frustration.\n\nBut what's here is still excellent.  If you are a fan of the original game or DuckTales in general
hoursPlayed: you should consider it."

reviewText: Having owned the original NES game, I definitely got my money's worth when I bought the remaster; HOWEVER, admittedly, the cutscenes, while entertaining the first couple times, seem to lose their flavor after that. This could also be due to the fact that I didn't grow up heavily with the show, which is likely the main reason why these cutscenes were in there to begin with. My personal recommendation is definitely get it if you want to, but I would do so while it's on sale (I've usually seen it at around $7.50); since this is a remaster of an NES game, it's fairly short, and there are not a lot of achievements (for at least the PC version). Honestly, I don't play it that much anymore, since I have all the achievements, but I definitely felt like I got my money's worth out of a trip down memory lane.\n\nTL;DR: Wait until it's on sale if you want to buy it.

reviewText: First off, I really enjoyed this game, it was nostalgic to say the least to play a game that i enjoyed as a kid, plus I loved the tv series as well.  So naturally, I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and it stayed true to the original.  So why don't I recommend it than?  Well... the game hasn't been supported by the developers since November of 2013, and a lot of newer post patch video cards are having issues with this game.   Myself for instance, I can't beat the game because upon defeating the final boss, my game freezes every single time, which has been reported by a host of other newer players.\n\nSo in summary, as much as I enjoyed the game, I can't in good conscience recommend this to anyone when the devs are not responding to players reporting issues, the game is no longer being supported, and this freezing bug persists.  Really Valve should pull this off of the store, or at least put a large disclaimer indicating that this title is un-compatible with newer video cards post November of 2013.   Regardless, this issue is incredibly frustrating, and it's anger inducing to be met with the sound of crickets from the developers, who've essentially abandoned this game.  Purchase at your own risk.

reviewText:
Life is like a hurricane...here in Duckburg!...

Not only is this game a lot of fun, it definitely brings me back to childhood. I spent many a happy hour watching DuckTales and when I saw this game, I couldn't resist. I'd played the original when I was a kid and was so sad when we lost the game when we moved.

Imagine my surprise when I saw it was remastered!
Now, I'm pretty sure that we all had the first thought--would it be as good as the original?
Don't worry--it is.
It's better!

The music, the graphics, the familiar faces and names...they're all there and the game is great. It's got Easy, Medium and Hard settings, so you can decide how to play as well, which is a perk to me. Haha. OH and the voice talents are phenominal. I loved hearing Scrooge's witty retorts and Huey, Dewey and Louie's Unca Scrooge!"

All in all--a great game and the nostalgia is wonderful.

And c'mon--I know you're singing the theme song with me now

reviewText:
Ducktales Remastered is a fantastic remake of the first Ducktales game that was for the Nintendo Entertainment System back in 1989. The new music sounds great, the gameplay is just as good as it ever was (not to mention you can change the pogo settings to whichever you're more comfortable with), and the cutscenes really captured the spirit of the show, especially since most of the old voice actors reprised their roles.

The difficulty selection is a nice feature for those who either want to just breeze through the game without too much of a problem or jump right into the harder modes that the original NES game was known for. Not to mention that any money that you collect throughout your adventures can be used to purchase things in the gallery such as game artwork, music of the game's soundtrack, to even art from the TV show! Or you can just swim in your earnings in the Money Bin. That works too. Plus, after beating the game at least once, you can play the game with the 8-bit soundtrack, which includes the NES soundtrack and 8-bit versions of the new music added in this game. Though, I'm kinda disappointed that they didn't make an 8-bit version of the Final Boss theme, but oh well.

Overall, Ducktales is definitely a game that I recommend to those looking for a good side-scrolling platformer, those who are Disney/Capcom/WayForward fans, & those who grew up with Ducktales, whether it'd be the show and/or the video games. In any case, I'm going to wait for the day that they'll make another Remastered game based on another hit show from the Disney Afternoon, but only time will tell when that day will come.

reviewText:
Ducktales remastered is a remake of the classic NES game. I’ve never played the original NES game, so even without the nostalgia glasses, I still think Ducktales remastered is a wonderful game with some minor flaws.

The game features a 2.5d look with hand drawn sprites and backgrounds and they look amazing. The redone themes are catchy, memorable, and kickass. They also brought back the original actors to voice the characters. The controls are tight and responsive. There is plenty to unlock with the gems you collect from character art, music, and even sketches from the show.

Some of my minor gripes with the game are the cut scenes are fairly frequent and take you out of the experience. Every time you find an item there’s a cut scene. While you can skip them you have to do so manually, there is no option to skip all cut scenes.

Ducktales also isn’t for everyone. It features the classic NES difficulty if you lose all your lives you have to replay the level from the start. I found the game to be challenging but fair. The game only became frustrating at the very end where you have race to the top.

Overall Ducktales is a great and challenging platforming game that still holds up well after two decades.

reviewText:
This game is a rollercoster of my childhood memory. As a kid, I grew up playing videogames a lot and Duck Tales is one of my favourite games. So I was really looking forward to the remake.

The remake, however, does not live up to my expectation.

Pros: Enhanced graphic and stuff to buy in game.
Nostalgic memory. It is really nice to hear that catchy intro tune again!
The non-linear stages from NES version is still good as in once was. You could choose whichever stage you like first.

Cons. Quite buggy. I lost my safe THREE times. Not sure how could this happen so I decided to do a marathon to finish it on a single play.
Scrooge is quite unresponsive to control sometimes. Especially the last boss battle where you would need precision.


Conclusion. Buy it if you want a reminiscing moment. Don't buy it if you are new to this

reviewText:
Here's my review of Duck Tales Remastered:

PROS:
-Fun and well controlled gameplay.
-Controlls well with both gamepad and keyboard & mouse.
-Maps/levels are greatly designed and just like the original as far as I've seen.
-Feels a lot like the TV show.
-The game is challenging, giving you a feeling of accomplishment when you finish a level.

CONS:
-The cutscenes can sometimes feel like they're interrupting gameplay.
-Sometimes can be frustratingly difficult.
-I've experienced some graphical glitches like sprites disappearing and reappearing (flashing back and forth)

SUMMARY:
Some people say that this game is inferior to the original on the NES and only worth it for fans of the original, I dissagree. This game is just like the original with added story as far as I've seen. I hadn't seen the show and never heard of the original until this one, and I still love playing this, so I'd say it's worth it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Ducktales Remastered is a fine reimagining of the classic NES game. The five stages from the original game are faithfully reproduced in stunning hi-res graphics, the music is a phenomenal reimagining of the original 8-bit tunes, and the addition of voice acting (by and large using the voice actors from the old Disney cartoon!) tickles the nostalgia bone on an additional level.

My only real point of complaint is the addition of a final, sixth level in which the game's end boss is found and battled. The problem lies not so much with the level itself, or even with the post-final-boss Metroid-esque escape sequence which is an incredibly unforgiving gauntlet of instant-death hazards that requires both memorization and reflexes to pass. No, the problem is that losing all of your lives during that escape sequence kicks the player right back to the beginning of the final stage, forcing him or her to slog through its entirety again. It struck me as unfun padding in an otherwise tight, high-quality game.

That said, DuckTales: Remastered is a great nostalgia kick for people who grew up playing the original NES game, and it is overall put together quite well. Players who did not grow up on the original, however, might be put off by its comparatively short length, but anyone looking for a fun platforming romp should enjoy the game.

reviewText:
If it ain't broke, don't fix it.  Wayforward got it right.  Keep what made the original such a memorable classic (essentially the whole game!), and throw a fresh coat of paint on it.

The presentation and voicework is great - it has the feel of a Ducktales episode.  However, even though this game has tons of personality, only get the game if it's discounted - the $15 price tag is too high. Unless you want to get all the achievements, you can beat the game in one or two sittings as the length the game is rather short.

reviewText: Nicely remastered - doesn't feel forced with the familiar cartoon style. It is a bit of a short/simple (you can see there's lots of work put into it though) game considering it costs 14€ but I don't personally feel cheated because there's difficulty levels for everyone (even for the most demanding). I managed to rage on the Easy level though so if you are not too into platformers you might wanna prepare yourself for mild frustrations. Also there are cut scenes that might seem a little childish to some but you can skip them which is a excellent feature in that case. Overall the game runs excellent on this older computer of mine. If I have to think anything negative it would be the lack of volume control in-game but you can easily lower it manually from your computer.

reviewText:
I beat the game, but didn't get all the achievements.

This game is quite easy to play and really resembles the NES classic from years ago. That said, it also has harder modes for people who like challenges.

The game is very well animated, with gorgeous visuals, and all the dialog is dubbed in english. I'm not american but I presume the voices are pretty accurate with the cartoon, since they resemble quite a lot the voices of the version I've watched here where I live. Lots of the characters make an appearance, so it's pretty nostalgic for people who watched the cartoon.

It's not a very long game and doesn't require much skill to play. I presume everybody could enjoy this one.

reviewText: As someone who grew up with DuckTales and played the original NES game when it was released, this was a fun blast from the past. It retains a great deal of the nostalgia of the original, while adding an updated look without going overboard. The music is lovingly redone from its 8-bit origins, and the gameplay feels much like it did on the NES (with the exception that the controller is larger, but that's only because I played with an XBox controller). The addition of the voice cast from the cartoon, makes for a nice touch too, as it was nice to hear them again. Made me pull out my DVD collection to watch the series again, and it the process, introduce my 2 year old daughter to the cartoon (which she now asks for all the time).\nI know many had issue with the amount of cut scenes added, but I didn't find it too bad. After your first play through, simply turn off cutscenes through the options and you're good. It did find the game easier than I did the original, but I don't know if that was me remembering the NES original being harder from the mindset of my younger, early gamer years or that I've just grown better at gaming.\nOverall, I'd recommend this to anyone; fan of the original cartoon or not. It's a nice bit of nostalgia for those who are and a fun, classic-styled side-scroller for all.

reviewText:
just a note: This is a review being done by someone who never played the original, as I came into gaming late  in the SNES era/early PS era, and am currently on my second play through.

The pros of this game:

The Music- It is stellar.  I wish they would come out with a soundtrack for this game.  The music for the levels are unique and suit the environment and tone of the game.  I can't say whether it is better or worse then the 8Bit rendition.  Thusfar, I've only heard the Amazon level music and the Money bin version, and I don't care for either of those, but that still leaves a few levels worth of music to go.

Voice acting - Getting as many of the original voice actors from the cartoon as they could was a good call.  It made it seem like I was listening to the cartoon.

Level design - Overall was fairly good.  While there was some sticky points that they could have improved on (the finale, for instance), the levels were beautifully designed, appealing to the eye, and offered just enough challenge to keep you from getting bored but not so much that the game was frustrating.  Ending aside.

The Neutrals:

Cut scenes - While I enjoyed watching them generally, they suffered from the fact that the characters were 2D in a 2.5D setting, and as such were limited in what they could do.  Personally, I think the game would have benefitted from cutting down the actual cut scenes to main points (as in, cutting out the ones for individual items) and animating them as 2D cartoons.

Difficulties - There are multiple ones.  Nothing really all that special about it.

The Cons:

Lag - This may have just been an issue with my rig, but there was an odd amount of lag in the game.  While my computer generally is able to handle harder hitting games, it was bogged down by this game, which meant the game hesitated - oddly, this presented as pauses in dialogue and cut scenes, and as slower animation throughout the game, but somehow didn't hinder actual gameplay.

The Gallery - While the gallery as a concept is excellent, and I love the idea of using the money you gain in the levels to buy the extras, the fact you had to unlock so much from one section to unlock the next area to buy from seemed silly.  To me, it seemed like a ploy to force you to replay the game, just to get the content you wanted - which for me was the music and background imagary.

The ending gameplay - While I won't go into what the ending part actually was, I will say this:  In and of itself, the game ending was fairly good story-wise, but the execution of it was terrible when it came to gameplay.  This game had fairly even difficulty throughout, up until this segment - in which the difficulty randomly and suddenly spiked.  The overall design required a level of precision at points that made the game feel near impossible to finish, especially in comparison to the rest of the game.

While the game does have its faults, it's a good game overall.  I bought the game on sale, but likely would have bought it at its full price had I found it at that.  $15 is a steal considering the amount of work that went into making this game, and the sale prices even moreso.  While I can't vouch for the nostalgia of the game, for someone who is a fan of Ducktales and the richest duck in the world, I would definately suggest at least giving this game a shot.

reviewText:
Prepare to be injected with an overdose of nostalgia.

DuckTales Remastered, will carry you away back to your childhood. The Classic Capcom intro sent goosebumps down my spine and everything after it was not disappointing. Some minor gripes here and there.

There are hints of dubstep in some of the musical scores. Which can be overlooked, but really? Transylvania needs dubstep?

The game is a lot of fun and it holds up to the NES version in difficulty. You can spend hard earned money to unlock concept arts, character art and so on. If your someone who needs to unlock everything then there is plenty to do here.

I hope more remakes come out. Chip & Dale and Darkwing Duck would be excellent choices.

Above all I highly recommend this game to new and old gamers. You can't go wrong with solving mysteries or the possibility of rewriting history.

I give DuckTales: Remastered a 5/5.

For more reviews check out J&J Game
http://brutalgamereviewers.blogspot.com/2013/12/ducktales-remastered.html

reviewText:
An exellent remake of the original NES title. The graphics are clean, crisp and colorful. A true and faithful remake of the original. Controls are spot on (see below) and the flow is good. Desipite the levels being a bit small there is still some challenge to the game.

There are some issues with the controls. Sadly I could not play this with my original NES controller (NES to USB) and there are several others having issues with the controls even though it does sound like it will work with any controller, it does not. My Logictech F510 and F310 work flawlessly.

Overall I'm happy with my purchase and I give it a big thumbs up to anyone wanting to relive or just re-experience the NES classic. The original still holds a place on my shelf, but the Remastered addition is truly a classic in its own right.

reviewText:
A somewhat good modern day version of the NES classic. The game still feels fun to play, but the stages just lack the awesomeness factor for me. The boss fights are awesome and definitely the most fun part about the game until...

Yes, the last part of the last level. You have two segments after the actual boss fight. Sure, the original title had the coin-chasing race and it was hard enough in the original title and meets the expectations in this one as well. But there's more to come even after that. The level that makes you realize just how clunky the controls in this game actually are as it requires extreme precision and makes so many players ragequit as grinding through the whole level over and over again without losing a single life to have another proper shot at the last segment is just frustrating. I have no problem with games being hard and frustrating as an avid fan of roguelikes, but this game just takes it to a whole new level of frustration because it's all caused by controls.

I'm kinda on the fence about this title. It's not that expensive so it will most likely be appealing enough for the money for many. It's just sad that the game could have been so much better with some more effort put into the controls and level design.

reviewText:
DuckTales! Woo-oo!

Capcom's most cherished 8-bit Classic (besides the Mega Man series) is back, and completely remastered! Join Scrooge McDuck and his nephews Huey, Dewey, and Louie, as they travel to collect the most ancient treasures! You'll be travelling to locations suck as the Amazon, the Himalayan Mountains, and even the Moon! You can even swim in Scrooge's money bin, a feature that you previously could not do in the classic. What's more, you can unlock extra's with your money you find inside the game! You'll unlock extra's such as concept art, character designs, and even the music!

I completely recommend this game to anyone who was a fan of Disney back in the day. I rate this game a 9/10.

reviewText: Possibly one of the most misleading games of history. This is a remake of the NES classic which was made by Capcom in the Mega Man era (the original actually uses the Mega Man engine). If you've ever played any of the NES Mega Man games, this game takes a lot of cues from that series and is punishingly hard in places. Not recommended for children unless you are raising a retro fiend monster.\n\nExcellent game though and worth it if you like old school platformers.
